bibl.title: Letter from Landon Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 14, 1929

div1.p: Landon Reed writes about her husband Lawrence Reed's promotion to post inspector.

div1.head: Letter from Landon Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 14, 1929
div1.p:
ft. Bewing. Ga
Sept. 14th Dear Granny

I must write & tell
you about your distinguished
son as I am so proud of
him- You know as I wrote
Blossom he was relieved from
the 29th & weak Post Inspector
nell Monday afternoon his
Bott - gave him a farewell
parade - is was purely voluntary
& all officers & mene attended
it was most impressive to
see Lawrence standing at
attention & all the officers
saluting him & then Maj.
Taylor made a most com-
plimentary speech about the
honor of having served under
him & Lawrence made a
return speech & the photographer
have all around taking pictures
(which I will send you when
they come out) then we must
to these jaytons where they served
pounch & cake to the 1st Batt
on their lawn- Then Thursday
night the officers of the 1st
Batt (almost 25) gave him
a at the 29th ingty
Mass & every officers made
a speech - one man nearly
kept he was so overcome
& all said how they had
loved having under him etc
They sent me a box of the
most exquisite dahlias
I ever saw some pink
& some lavender & as
large as plates- There
Col. Peusleton sent him
a formal letter saying
he regreeted his learned
the rejt- &Saying the
2
most superlatively com-
plimentary things about
his work with the Batt-
but what pleased me to
was the way his officers
served to really ask him
due of thewives told
me they called him
“The Grand Old Man”
so altogether we are just
as set up as possible.

I enclose a note for Blossom
with the latest cat news-
& Lawrence will write tomorrow
almost her lonely birth day
present- The summer
has been better than I
expected - not as but as
last summer & very little
rain entirely too little
for the flowers & etry-
I have loved the swimming
pool where I spend from
an hour to an hour
and a half every afternoon.
I must stop now as on
go to a marching this afternoon
at the Polo Club - then
little Hocker girl marries
a little Lt. named Doidge
she looks like a pasty pie
& he a pasty cheese straw-

With love poem them
family & the “Graces
Old Man” if he were in-
